required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Study to Evaluate the Efficacy and Safety of AMG 714 in Adult Patients With Type II Refractory Celiac Disease
clinical_study.official_title: A Phase 2a, Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled, Parallel-Group Study to Evaluate the Efficacy and Safety of AMG 714 in Adult Patients With Type II Refractory Celiac Disease, an In Situ Small Bowel T Cell Lymphoma

brief_summary.textblock: Protocol CELIM-RCD-002 is designed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of AMG 714 for the treatment of adult patients with type II refractory celiac disease (RCD-II), an in-situ small bowel T-cell lymphoma.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: Percent Change From Baseline in the Percentage of Aberrant Intestinal Intraepithelial Lymphocytes With Respect to All Intraepithelial Lymphocytes
primary_outcome.description: The primary endpoint in this study was the change form baseline in the percentage of aberrant intestinal intraepithelial lymphocytes (IELs) with respect to total IELs, as assessed by flow cytometry (Immunological Response 1). Intraepithelial lymphocytes (IELS) are white blood cells interspersed between epithelial cells of the small and large intestine where they function to preserve the integrity of the mucosal barrier by protecting the epithelium against pathogen or immune-induced pathology. In refractory coeliac disease type 2, aberrant intraepithelial lymphocytes make up 20% or more of total intraepithelial lymphocytes. Aberrant IELs were defined by flow cytometry as surface cluster of differentiation (CD)3-negative, intracellular CD3-positive IELs (sCD3-, icCD3+).

secondary_outcome.measure: Percent Change From Baseline in the Percentage of Aberrant Intestinal Intraepithelial Lymphocytes With Respect to All Intestinal Epithelial Cells
secondary_outcome.description: Percent change from baseline in the percentage of aberrant intestinal IELs with respect to intestinal epithelial cells (Immunological Response 2) is a composite endpoint calculated by multiplying the percent of aberrant IEL versus total IELs (per flow cytometry) by the percent of total IEL versus intestinal epithelial cells as assessed by immunohistochemistry.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percent Change From Baseline in Villous Height to Crypt Depth (VH:CD) Ratio
secondary_outcome.description: Villi are the small fingerlike projections that line the small intestine and promote nutrient absorption and are often shortened in patients with celiac disease. Crypts are grooves between the villi that are often elongated in patients with celiac disease. A decreased VH:CD ratio indicates worsening disease and increases in the VH:CD ratio indicate an improvement in the histology of intestinal mucosa (Histological Response). Small bowel biopsies were performed at baseline and week 12; histological assessments were performed by a blinded central pathologist.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With Improvement in Marsh Score at Week 12
secondary_outcome.description: The Marsh classification system describes the stages of damage in the small intestine as seen under a microscope, with possible values of 0, 1, 2, 3a, 3b, or 3c. A score of 0 (best score) indicates that the intestinal lining is normal and celiac disease highly unlikely, a score of 3c (worst score) indicates increased intraepithelial lymphocytes, increased crypt hyperplasia and complete villi atrophy. Improvement is defined as a lower grade on the Marsh score scale compared to baseline.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percent Change From Baseline in Total Intraepithelial Lymphocyte Count at Week 12
secondary_outcome.description: Small bowel biopsies were performed at baseline and week 12; histological assessments were performed by a blinded central pathologist. The total IEL count is the density of IELs vs intestinal epithelial cells measured by immunohistochemistry.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Weekly Bowel Movements at Baseline and Week 12
secondary_outcome.description: Participants were asked to record every bowel movement during the study using an electronic diary. If no bowel movements were experienced by the participant on any given day, the participant was required to document this in the diary.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With Diarrhea at Baseline and Week 12
secondary_outcome.description: The Bristol Stool Form Scale (BSFS) is a pictorial aid to help participants identify the shape and consistency of their bowel movements. Participants were asked to complete this form daily using an electronic diary at the time of each bowel movement. The BSFS categorizes bowel movements into 7 types, from Type 1 (separate hard lumps, like nuts; hard to pass) to Type 7 (watery, no solid pieces, entirely liquid). Diarrhoea was defined at least one BSFS score >= 6 for the given week.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Total Weekly Gastrointestinal Symptom Rating Scale (GSRS) Score at Week 12
secondary_outcome.description: The GSRS is a 15-question 7-scale questionnaire used to assess 5 dimensions of gastrointestinal syndromes: diarrhea, indigestion, constipation, abdominal pain and reflux. Questions are scored between 1 (no discomfort at all) and 7 (very severe discomfort). The total GSRS score is calculated as the sum of the scores of all 15 questions, and ranges from 15 (no discomfort at all) to 105 (very severe discomfort in all 5 dimensions of gastrointestinal syndromes).

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Total Celiac Disease GSRS (CeD-GSRS) Score at Week 12
secondary_outcome.description: The CeD-GSRS score is derived from a subset of 10 questions from the GSRS questionnaire (questions 1, 4-9, 11, 12 and 14), which are each assessed on a scale of 1 (no discomfort at all) to 7 (very severe discomfort). The total CeD-GSRS score ranges from 10 (no discomfort at all) to 70 (very severe discomfort in all celiac syndromes).

arm_group.description: Participants were administered 8 mg/kg AMG 714 via intravenous infusion on day 0, day 7 and every 2 weeks thereafter through week 10.
Participants were administered placebo via intravenous infusion on day 0, day 7 and every 2 weeks thereafter through week 10.

intervention.description: Administered via a 120-minute IV infusion for a total of 7 times over 10 weeks.
Administered via a 120-minute IV infusion for a total of 7 times over 10 weeks.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Confirmed diagnosis of refractory celiac disease Type II (RCD-II)
- Greater than 20% aberrant intraepithelial lymphocytes (IEL) as assessed by flow cytometry
- On a gluten-free diet for at least 6 months
- Avoid pregnancy
Exclusion Criteria:
- Enteropathy-Associated T cell Lymphoma (EATL)
- Infections
- Immune suppression
- Clinically significant co-morbidities

participant_flow.recruitment_details: This study was conducted at 6 sites in France, Netherlands, Finland, Spain, and the United States. Participants with previously confirmed diagnosis of refractory coeliac disease (RCD) type 2 were enrolled from April 13, 2016 to January 19, 2017.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Participants were randomized in a 2:1 ratio to receive either 8 mg/kg AMG 714 or placebo. Randomization and initial dosing of the first 10 participants were staggered to allow observation for any possible unanticipated side effects.

group.title: AMG 714
group.description: Participants were administered 8 mg/kg AMG 714 via intravenous infusion on day 0, day 7 and every 2 weeks thereafter through week 10.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Participants were administered placebo via intravenous infusion on day 0, day 7 and every 2 weeks thereafter through week 10.

group.description: Participants were administered 8 mg/kg AMG 714 via intravenous infusion on day 0, day 7 and every 2 weeks thereafter through week 10.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Participants were administered placebo via intravenous infusion on day 0, day 7 and every 2 weeks thereafter through week 10.

group.title: Total
group.description: Total of all reporting groups

measure.title: Percentage of Aberrant Intestinal Intraepithelial Lymphocytes (IELs) Versus Total IELs
measure.description: Aberrant IELs were defined by flow cytometry as surface cluster of differentiation (CD)3-negative, intra-cellular CD3-positive IELs (sCD3-, icCD3+).
measure.population: The per protocol (PP) population included participants who received study drug and provided evaluable data for efficacy analysis, excluded non-evaluable participants and those with major protocol deviations. Participants with atypical RCD-II were also excluded.

outcome.title: Percent Change From Baseline in the Percentage of Aberrant Intestinal Intraepithelial Lymphocytes With Respect to All Intraepithelial Lymphocytes
outcome.description: The primary endpoint in this study was the change form baseline in the percentage of aberrant intestinal intraepithelial lymphocytes (IELs) with respect to total IELs, as assessed by flow cytometry (Immunological Response 1). Intraepithelial lymphocytes (IELS) are white blood cells interspersed between epithelial cells of the small and large intestine where they function to preserve the integrity of the mucosal barrier by protecting the epithelium against pathogen or immune-induced pathology. In refractory coeliac disease type 2, aberrant intraepithelial lymphocytes make up 20% or more of total intraepithelial lymphocytes. Aberrant IELs were defined by flow cytometry as surface cluster of differentiation (CD)3-negative, intracellular CD3-positive IELs (sCD3-, icCD3+).
outcome.population: The per protocol (PP) population included participants who received study drug and provided evaluable data for efficacy analysis, excluded non-evaluable participants and those with major protocol deviations. Participants with atypical RCD-II were also excluded from analyses of Immunological Response 1.

group.title: AMG 714
group.description: Participants were administered 8 mg/kg AMG 714 via intravenous infusion on day 0, day 7 and every 2 weeks thereafter through week 10.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Participants were administered placebo via intravenous infusion on day 0, day 7 and every 2 weeks thereafter through week 10.

measure.title: Percent Change From Baseline in the Percentage of Aberrant Intestinal Intraepithelial Lymphocytes With Respect to All Intraepithelial Lymphocytes
measure.description: The primary endpoint in this study was the change form baseline in the percentage of aberrant intestinal intraepithelial lymphocytes (IELs) with respect to total IELs, as assessed by flow cytometry (Immunological Response 1). Intraepithelial lymphocytes (IELS) are white blood cells interspersed between epithelial cells of the small and large intestine where they function to preserve the integrity of the mucosal barrier by protecting the epithelium against pathogen or immune-induced pathology. In refractory coeliac disease type 2, aberrant intraepithelial lymphocytes make up 20% or more of total intraepithelial lymphocytes. Aberrant IELs were defined by flow cytometry as surface cluster of differentiation (CD)3-negative, intracellular CD3-positive IELs (sCD3-, icCD3+).
measure.population: The per protocol (PP) population included participants who received study drug and provided evaluable data for efficacy analysis, excluded non-evaluable participants and those with major protocol deviations. Participants with atypical RCD-II were also excluded from analyses of Immunological Response 1.

analysis.method_desc: Analysis of covariance (ANCOVA) with baseline % aberrant IELs vs total IELs as a covariate and treatment group as a fixed effect.

outcome.title: Percent Change From Baseline in the Percentage of Aberrant Intestinal Intraepithelial Lymphocytes With Respect to All Intestinal Epithelial Cells
outcome.description: Percent change from baseline in the percentage of aberrant intestinal IELs with respect to intestinal epithelial cells (Immunological Response 2) is a composite endpoint calculated by multiplying the percent of aberrant IEL versus total IELs (per flow cytometry) by the percent of total IEL versus intestinal epithelial cells as assessed by immunohistochemistry.
outcome.population: The per protocol (PP) population included participants who received study drug and provided evaluable data for efficacy analysis, excluded non-evaluable participants and those with major protocol deviations. Participants with atypical RCD-II were also excluded from analyses of Immunological Response 2.

measure.description: Percent change from baseline in the percentage of aberrant intestinal IELs with respect to intestinal epithelial cells (Immunological Response 2) is a composite endpoint calculated by multiplying the percent of aberrant IEL versus total IELs (per flow cytometry) by the percent of total IEL versus intestinal epithelial cells as assessed by immunohistochemistry.
measure.population: The per protocol (PP) population included participants who received study drug and provided evaluable data for efficacy analysis, excluded non-evaluable participants and those with major protocol deviations. Participants with atypical RCD-II were also excluded from analyses of Immunological Response 2.

analysis.method_desc: ANCOVA model with baseline % aberrant IELs vs intestinal epithelial cells as a covariate and treatment group as a fixed effect.

outcome.description: Villi are the small fingerlike projections that line the small intestine and promote nutrient absorption and are often shortened in patients with celiac disease. Crypts are grooves between the villi that are often elongated in patients with celiac disease. A decreased VH:CD ratio indicates worsening disease and increases in the VH:CD ratio indicate an improvement in the histology of intestinal mucosa (Histological Response). Small bowel biopsies were performed at baseline and week 12; histological assessments were performed by a blinded central pathologist.

outcome.title: Percentage of Participants With Improvement in Marsh Score at Week 12
outcome.description: The Marsh classification system describes the stages of damage in the small intestine as seen under a microscope, with possible values of 0, 1, 2, 3a, 3b, or 3c. A score of 0 (best score) indicates that the intestinal lining is normal and celiac disease highly unlikely, a score of 3c (worst score) indicates increased intraepithelial lymphocytes, increased crypt hyperplasia and complete villi atrophy. Improvement is defined as a lower grade on the Marsh score scale compared to baseline.

measure.title: Percentage of Participants With Improvement in Marsh Score at Week 12
measure.description: The Marsh classification system describes the stages of damage in the small intestine as seen under a microscope, with possible values of 0, 1, 2, 3a, 3b, or 3c. A score of 0 (best score) indicates that the intestinal lining is normal and celiac disease highly unlikely, a score of 3c (worst score) indicates increased intraepithelial lymphocytes, increased crypt hyperplasia and complete villi atrophy. Improvement is defined as a lower grade on the Marsh score scale compared to baseline.

outcome.description: Small bowel biopsies were performed at baseline and week 12; histological assessments were performed by a blinded central pathologist. The total IEL count is the density of IELs vs intestinal epithelial cells measured by immunohistochemistry.

measure.title: Percent Change From Baseline in Total Intraepithelial Lymphocyte Count at Week 12

analysis.method_desc: ANCOVA) model with baseline total IEL counts as a covariate and treatment group as a fixed effect.

outcome.title: Number of Weekly Bowel Movements at Baseline and Week 12
outcome.description: Participants were asked to record every bowel movement during the study using an electronic diary. If no bowel movements were experienced by the participant on any given day, the participant was required to document this in the diary.
outcome.population: The intent-to-treat population consisted of all randomized participants who had received at least one dose of the study drug.

group.title: AMG 714
group.description: Participants were administered 8 mg/kg AMG 714 via intravenous infusion on day 0, day 7 and every 2 weeks thereafter through week 10.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Participants were administered placebo via intravenous infusion on day 0, day 7 and every 2 weeks thereafter through week 10.

measure.title: Number of Weekly Bowel Movements at Baseline and Week 12
measure.description: Participants were asked to record every bowel movement during the study using an electronic diary. If no bowel movements were experienced by the participant on any given day, the participant was required to document this in the diary.
measure.population: The intent-to-treat population consisted of all randomized participants who had received at least one dose of the study drug.

analysis.method_desc: Generalized linear mixed model with subject as a random effect and treatment group, time (week) and their interaction as fixed effects.

outcome.title: Percentage of Participants With Diarrhea at Baseline and Week 12
outcome.description: The Bristol Stool Form Scale (BSFS) is a pictorial aid to help participants identify the shape and consistency of their bowel movements. Participants were asked to complete this form daily using an electronic diary at the time of each bowel movement. The BSFS categorizes bowel movements into 7 types, from Type 1 (separate hard lumps, like nuts; hard to pass) to Type 7 (watery, no solid pieces, entirely liquid). Diarrhoea was defined at least one BSFS score >= 6 for the given week.

group.description: Participants were administered 8 mg/kg AMG 714 via intravenous infusion on day 0, day 7 and every 2 weeks thereafter through week 10.

group.description: Participants were administered placebo via intravenous infusion on day 0, day 7 and every 2 weeks thereafter through week 10.

measure.title: Percentage of Participants With Diarrhea at Baseline and Week 12
measure.description: The Bristol Stool Form Scale (BSFS) is a pictorial aid to help participants identify the shape and consistency of their bowel movements. Participants were asked to complete this form daily using an electronic diary at the time of each bowel movement. The BSFS categorizes bowel movements into 7 types, from Type 1 (separate hard lumps, like nuts; hard to pass) to Type 7 (watery, no solid pieces, entirely liquid). Diarrhoea was defined at least one BSFS score >= 6 for the given week.

outcome.title: Change From Baseline in Total Weekly Gastrointestinal Symptom Rating Scale (GSRS) Score at Week 12
outcome.description: The GSRS is a 15-question 7-scale questionnaire used to assess 5 dimensions of gastrointestinal syndromes: diarrhea, indigestion, constipation, abdominal pain and reflux. Questions are scored between 1 (no discomfort at all) and 7 (very severe discomfort). The total GSRS score is calculated as the sum of the scores of all 15 questions, and ranges from 15 (no discomfort at all) to 105 (very severe discomfort in all 5 dimensions of gastrointestinal syndromes).

group.description: Participants were administered 8 mg/kg AMG 714 via intravenous infusion on day 0, day 7 and every 2 weeks thereafter through week 10.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Participants were administered placebo via intravenous infusion on day 0, day 7 and every 2 weeks thereafter through week 10.

measure.title: Change From Baseline in Total Weekly Gastrointestinal Symptom Rating Scale (GSRS) Score at Week 12
measure.description: The GSRS is a 15-question 7-scale questionnaire used to assess 5 dimensions of gastrointestinal syndromes: diarrhea, indigestion, constipation, abdominal pain and reflux. Questions are scored between 1 (no discomfort at all) and 7 (very severe discomfort). The total GSRS score is calculated as the sum of the scores of all 15 questions, and ranges from 15 (no discomfort at all) to 105 (very severe discomfort in all 5 dimensions of gastrointestinal syndromes).

analysis.method_desc: Linear mixed effects repeated measures model with baseline value, treatment group, time point and time point-by-treatment group as fixed effects.

outcome.title: Change From Baseline in Total Celiac Disease GSRS (CeD-GSRS) Score at Week 12
outcome.description: The CeD-GSRS score is derived from a subset of 10 questions from the GSRS questionnaire (questions 1, 4-9, 11, 12 and 14), which are each assessed on a scale of 1 (no discomfort at all) to 7 (very severe discomfort). The total CeD-GSRS score ranges from 10 (no discomfort at all) to 70 (very severe discomfort in all celiac syndromes).

measure.description: The CeD-GSRS score is derived from a subset of 10 questions from the GSRS questionnaire (questions 1, 4-9, 11, 12 and 14), which are each assessed on a scale of 1 (no discomfort at all) to 7 (very severe discomfort). The total CeD-GSRS score ranges from 10 (no discomfort at all) to 70 (very severe discomfort in all celiac syndromes).

analysis.method_desc: Linear mixed effects repeated measures model with baseline value, treatment group, time point and a time point-by-treatment group as fixed effects.

reported_events.time_frame: From first dose of study drug until week 16.
reported_events.desc: Other Adverse Events summarizes the non-serious occurrences of adverse events that exceed the indicated frequency threshold.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: The Clinical Trial Agreement generally does not restrict an investigator's discussion of trial results after completion. The Agreement permits Amgen a limited period of time to review material discussing trial results (typically up to 45 days and possible extension). Amgen may remove confidential information, but authors have final control and approval of publication content. For multicenter studies, the investigator agrees not to publish any results before the first multi-center publication.
